background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: left"&gt;June 30, 2015&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 17.25pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:MarketableSecuritiesTextBlock>    <ALAN:AlancoEnergyServicesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During fiscal 2012, the Company formed&#13;Alanco Energy Services, Inc. (&amp;#147;AES&amp;#148;), a wholly-owned subsidiary, and in April 2012 executed an agreement with TC Operating,&#13;LLC (&amp;#34;TCO&amp;#34;) of Grand Junction, CO to transfer a land lease for approximately 24 acres near Grand Junction, CO and all&#13;related assets to AES with the intent for AES to construct facilities for the treatment and disposal of large quantities of produced&#13;water generated by oil and natural gas producers in Western Colorado. The site was chosen due to its unique ability to meet stringent&#13;government requirements for disposal of the high saline water produced as a by-product of oil and gas production, and termed &amp;#34;produced&#13;water&amp;#34;. The agreement included the transfer of all related tangible and intangible assets as well as Federal, State and County&#13;permits (issued or in process) required to construct the facilities. The lease terms payable to the landlord include a minimum&#13;monthly lease payment of $100 per acre ($2,400 per month) during the initial ten year term of the lease, plus approximately $.25&#13;per barrel of produced water received at the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The design and construction of the&#13;Deer Creek water disposal facility required certain changes to the Goodwin Solid Waste facility (&amp;#147;Goodwin&amp;#148;) resulting&#13;in extra costs to the landlord, who also owned Goodwin. As incentive for the landlord to approve the facility design, AES agreed&#13;to limit landlord construction improvement costs related to the leased land to $200,000. Included in the $200,000 limited amount&#13;was $100,000 of landlord improvement costs to be paid by AES and reimbursed through a 50% credit against the $.25 per barrel royalty&#13;payments due landlord discussed above. AES recorded the $100,000 payment as prepaid royalties and under the current terms of the&#13;agreement, expired on August 31, 2015. The remaining prepaid balances at June 30, 2015 and 2014 were $5,100 and $58,700, respectively.&#13;The June 30, 2015 balance of $5,100, which is included in &amp;#147;Prepaid expenses and other current assets&amp;#148; on the balance&#13;sheet, is net of a $20,000 write down of the prepaid which is based on an estimate that the Company plans to recoup under the current&#13;agreement.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 17.25pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;TCO can also earn additional purchase&#13;price payments based upon a percentage of the net cumulative EBITDA (net of all related AES capital investments) over a period&#13;of approximately 10 years (contingent deferred payment), approximately the initial term of the lease. Under certain circumstances,&#13;the acreage covered by the lease may be expanded by up to 50 acres to allow for additional expansion at the site. See Note 8 -&#13;Contingent Payments for additional discussion of the contingent deferred payment.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During April 2012, AES also entered&#13;into a definitive agreement with Deer Creek Disposal, LLC (&amp;#34;DCD&amp;#34;) whereby AES acquired a 160 acre site near Grand Junction,&#13;CO, for additional expansion to the proposed water treatment and disposal facility. As consideration for the land purchase, AES&#13;paid $500,000 at the April 13, 2012 closing and assumed a non-interest bearing, secured, $200,000 note due November 15, 2012, which&#13;was repaid upon maturity. AES has also agreed to potential additional quarterly earn-out payments to DCD up to a maximum total&#13;of $800,000, generally determined as 10% of quarterly revenues in excess of operating expenses up to $200,000 per quarter (contingent&#13;land payment). See Note 8 - Contingent Payments for additional discussion of the contingent land payment. The land, known as Indian&#13;Mesa, is currently undeveloped. In June 2014 AES received final construction approval from the Colorado Department of Public Health&#13;and Environment (CDPHE) for twelve produced water disposal ponds, which if developed as planned, would be located on the north&#13;80 acres of the Indian Mesa site. The Company is in the permitting process for the remaining 80 acres.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Related to the treatment and disposal&#13;facilities, in fiscal year 2012 AES entered into a management agreement with TCO to manage the project for a monthly management&#13;fee of $10,000 initially and $20,000 after final permits for the Deer Creek operation were obtained in May 2012. The management&#13;agreement expired in January 2013 and continued on a month to month basis through March 31, 2015, at which time the Company elected&#13;not to continue the month to month arrangement. During the fiscal year ended June 30, 2015, the Company paid TCO approximately&#13;$185,000 under the management agreement. Effective April 1, 2015, the Company entered into an agreement for operations management&#13;services for the Deer Creek facility with a separate management company. The agreement is cancellable by either party at any time.&lt;/p&gt;</ALAN:AlancoEnergyServicesDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The assets of StarTrak Systems, LLC&#13;(&amp;#147;StarTrak&amp;#148;), a subsidiary comprising the Company&amp;#146;s Wireless Asset Management segment, were sold to ORBCOMM Inc.&#13;(&amp;#147;ORBCOMM&amp;#148;) effective in May 2011. The transaction was structured as an asset purchase whereby ORBCOMM acquired substantially&#13;all of StarTrak&amp;#146;s assets and liabilities. The transaction closing date was May 16, 2011.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Consideration Received - &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;Total&#13;transaction consideration payable at close, including escrowed amounts as required by the agreement, for substantially all of the&#13;assets of StarTrak is equal to an aggregate face amount of approximately $17.7 million in cash, ORBCOMM Common and Series A Preferred&#13;Stock, Alanco Common and Series E Preferred Stock and the assumption of debt. Consideration consisted of the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;1.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Cash consideration in an amount equal to two million dollars ($2,000,000)&#13;less any amount due under the secured loan referred to in 3 below;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;5.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Delivery to Alanco of 1,212,748 shares of Alanco Class A Common Stock&#13;with a closing value of $1.03 per share;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;6.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Issuance and delivery to Mellon Investor Services LLC, as escrow agent,&#13;(&amp;#147;Mellon&amp;#148;) of 249,917 shares of ORBCOMM common stock (&amp;#147;ORBCOMM Stock&amp;#148;) registered in the name of Alanco&#13;and valued at closing at $2.91 per share, which escrowed shares will be available to pay for half of the out of pocket costs incurred&#13;as a result of certain litigation against StarTrak;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;7.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;The issuance and delivery to Mellon, as escrow agent of 166,611 shares&#13;of ORBCOMM Stock, valued at closing at $2.91 per share, registered in the name of Alanco, which escrowed shares will be available&#13;to pay for a portion of certain product warranty costs;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;8.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;The issuance and delivery to Alanco of 1,820,583 shares of ORBCOMM&#13;Stock, valued at closing at $2.91 per share;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;9.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;The issuance and delivery to Alanco of 183,550 shares of Series A&#13;Perpetual Convertible Preferred ORBCOMM stock (&amp;#147;ORBCOMM Series A&amp;#148;) with a face value of $10 per share, entitled to&#13;a 4% annual paid-in-kind dividend and each such share convertible into 1.666 shares of ORBCOMM Stock; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 27.35pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;&lt;b&gt;10.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Assumption by ORBCOMM of certain specified liabilities, generally&#13;consisting of liabilities arising after the closing date and liabilities reflected in the closing Working Capital Adjustment (&amp;#147;WCA&amp;#148;).&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Product Warranty Escrow&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&#13;- The escrow account for 249,917 shares (number 6 above) of ORBCOMM Common Stock, established under the escrow agreement described&#13;above, provided for the availability of ORBCOMM shares to pay for half of the out of pocket costs that may be incurred as a result&#13;of certain litigation pending against StarTrak at the time of the closing. Subsequent to the closing, a settlement was reached&#13;among the litigants and ORBCOMM notified Alanco that its half of the settlement cost, including fees and expenses, amounted to&#13;approximately $100,000. Under the escrow agreement, the shares returned to ORBCOMM in payment of the litigation costs, would be&#13;valued at $3.001 per share. Final negotiation of the litigation escrow shares was completed in May 2012 and the agreement resulted&#13;in 29,990 of the escrow shares being distributed to ORBCOMM with the 219,927 balance distributed to Alanco.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The second escrow account in the amount&#13;of 166,611 shares of ORBCOMM common stock, established under item 7 above, provided for the availability of ORBCOMM shares to pay&#13;for half of certain product warranty costs incurred during the period March 1, 2011 to April 30, 2012, but only to the extent total&#13;warranty costs during the period exceed $600,000 (&amp;#147;fuel sensor escrow&amp;#148;). Under the escrow agreement, shares returned&#13;to ORBCOMM in payment of those warranty costs would again be valued at $3.001 per share. Upon distribution of the required shares&#13;to ORBCOMM, if any, from the escrow account, the remaining shares would be distributed to Alanco.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Working Capital Adjustment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&#13;&amp;#150; The Asset Purchase Agreement also provided compensation for changes in working capital between November 30, 2010 and May&#13;31, 2011, the measurement date, determined in accordance with GAAP consistently applied. If working capital, defined as current&#13;assets minus current liabilities less long-term deferred revenue, increased over the period, ORBCOMM was to pay the value of that&#13;increase in cash or additional ORBCOMM Common Stock under number 10 above. If the defined working capital decreased during the&#13;period, Alanco was to return that amount from ORBCOMM Common Stock, valued at $3.001 per share, issued under number 10 above.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;ORBCOMM delivered to Alanco on August&#13;12, 2011, a written statement of the Current Assets, Current Liabilities and Net Working Capital Amount pursuant to the terms of&#13;the Agreement reflecting a working capital adjustment in favor of ORBCOMM of approximately $700,000. Under terms of the Agreement,&#13;Alanco submitted a &amp;#147;Notice of Disagreement&amp;#148; of the Net Working Capital Amount submitted by ORBCOMM.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Settlement of Working Capital&#13;Adjustment and Product Warranty Escrow &amp;#150; &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;In February 2014, the parties negotiated a general settlement for the working&#13;capital adjustment and all product warranty liabilities. The agreement, effective February 24, 2014, required a) ORBCOMM to release&#13;to Alanco all ORBCOMM Common Shares (166,611 shares) held in the warranty escrow account; b) Alanco to pay ORBCOMM $691,000; c)&#13;ORBCOMM (through its StarTrak subsidiary) to pay a past due Alanco invoice in the amount of approximately $48,000 and required&#13;both parties to agree to provisions of a general mutual release. The effect of the settlement was to give Alanco the ability to&#13;sell the 166,611 ORBCOMM shares held in escrow and increased Alanco&amp;#146;s gain on sale of its StarTrak subsidiary, by $121,700,&#13;which is included in other income for the year ended June 30, 2014.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Land and permit costs at June 30, 2015&#13;represent costs related to the acquisition and permitting of 160 acres known as Indian Mesa. Costs include the initial payment&#13;at closing of $500,000, a $200,000 assumed note payable due and paid in November 2012, $625,000 present value of future contingent&#13;land payments, $307,700 in permit costs and $12,900 in legal expenses.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Water disposal facility assets at June&#13;30, 2015 consist of $1,809,200 in costs related to the construction and permitting of the evaporation ponds and $410,000 in asset&#13;retirement cost. The prior year included $500,000 for the fair value of the contingent purchase price liability and related accumulated&#13;depreciation of $48,900. In addition, $25,000 of deprecation was recorded in the current year for a total accumulated depreciation&#13;of $73,900, all of which has been reversed against cost of goods sold in the current year based on the parameters of the contingency&#13;and the estimated present value. Production equipment at June 30, 2015 of $514,400 represents the cost of equipment required to&#13;support the Deer Creek facility.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Related depreciation expense for the&#13;years ended June 30, 2015 and 2014 was $120,100 and $181,600, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:LegalMattersAndContingenciesTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;Contingent&#13;payments at June 30, 2015 and 2014 are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="color: red; width: 51%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; width: 2%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: center; width: 14%"&gt;2015&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 4%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; width: 2%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: center; width: 14%"&gt;2014&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Contingent land payment&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;653,900&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;660,200&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Contingent purchase price&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;528,100&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;653,900&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;1,188,300&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Less current portion&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;(50,000)&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;(50,000)&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Contingent payments, long-term&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;603,900&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;1,138,300&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Contingent&#13;land payment&lt;/b&gt; represents the net present value of $800,000 of contingent land payments due under an agreement whereby Alanco&#13;Energy Services, Inc. (&amp;#147;AES&amp;#148;) acquired 160 acres of land known as Indian Mesa. The maximum total of $800,000 of contingent land payments is based upon 10% of quarterly revenues in excess of operating expenses&#13;up to $200,000 per quarter for activity at both the Deer Creek and the Indian Mesa locations. The payments were projected considering current operating plans&#13;as approved by the Alanco Board of Directors, with the payments discounted at a rate of 3% per annum. During the fiscal year ended&#13;June 30, 2015 the Company incurred $8,600 in contingent land payments while $16,500 was incurred in fiscal year 2014. At June 30,&#13;2015, $3,300 was unpaid and included in accounts payable. See Note 5 &amp;#150; Alanco Energy Services for additional discussion on&#13;AES operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Contingent&#13;purchase price &lt;/b&gt;as of June 30, 2014 of $528,100&lt;b&gt; &lt;/b&gt;represents the net present value of projected payments to be made to&#13;TC Operating, LLC (&amp;#147;TCO&amp;#148;) pursuant to an Asset Purchase Agreement under which TCO transferred a land lease for approximately&#13;24 acres of land known as Deer Creek and all related tangible and intangible assets. As of June 30, 2015, based on the probability&#13;of the contingent payment being realized, the Company reversed the contingent purchase price liability of $500,000 and related&#13;accretion of $43,125 which was included in selling, general and administrative expense. Per the agreement, the contingent payments&#13;are determined as 28% of the Cumulative EBITDA in excess of all of AES&amp;#146;s capital investment for the ten (10) year period&#13;commencing on the earlier of (i) the recovery of AES&amp;#146;s capital investment, or (ii) January 1, 2014. AES&amp;#146;s Capital investment&#13;shall mean the aggregate amount incurred by AES in acquiring the Assets, the Indian Mesa Facility, and or improving either the&#13;Deer Creek Facility or the Indian Mesa Facility. Payments of said Contingent Purchase Price shall be payable quarterly. The projected&#13;payments consider current operating plans as approved by the Alanco Board of Directors, with payments discounted at a rate of 3%&#13;per annum to determine net present value.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The significant&#13;unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement of the Company&amp;#146;s fair value calculation for the contingent land payment&#13;and contingent purchase price is the probability of the contingent payments being realized, the timing of when the payments are&#13;paid and the discount rate applied. Significant changes in any of those inputs in isolation would result in a significantly different&#13;fair value measurement. See Note 5 &amp;#150; Alanco Energy Services for additional discussion on AES operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:LegalMattersAndContingenciesTextBlock>    <us-gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsAndEnvironmentalCostPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The Company&#13;initially recognized estimated asset retirement obligations (closure cost) at June 30, 2012 of $410,000 to remove leasehold improvements,&#13;remediate any pollution issues and return the Deer Creek water disposal property to its natural state at the conclusion of the&#13;Company&amp;#146;s lease. The closure process is a requirement of both the Deer Creek lease and the State of Colorado, a permitting&#13;authority for such facilities. The initial closure cost estimate, in then current dollars, was completed by an approved independent&#13;consultant experienced in estimating closure costs for water disposal operations and the estimated amount was approved by the State&#13;of Colorado.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 45.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The Company&#13;reviews the contingent asset retirement obligation on a recurring basis and records changes in the period incurred. At June 30,&#13;2015, the estimated closure costs were again reviewed and the only adjustment was a 1.014% inflation adjustment as required under&#13;agreement with the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, increasing the asset retirement obligation to $429,700,&#13;AES&amp;#146;s approximate 75% share of the $566,000 estimated closure costs for both the Deer Creek facility and the adjacent Goodwin&#13;Solid Waste facility (Goodwin is not owned by AES). At June 30, 2014, the only adjustment was a 1.015% inflation adjustment, increasing&#13;the asset retirement obligation to $423,700. The significant unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement of the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;fair value calculation for the asset retirement obligation include the estimated cost to close the Deer Creek facility in accordance&#13;with state approved closure plans, the projected timing of the closure and the discount rate applied. Significant changes in any&#13;of those inputs in isolation would result in a significantly different fair value measurement. See Note 5 &amp;#150; Alanco Energy&#13;Services for additional discussion on AES operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The laws of&#13;the State of Colorado require companies to meet environmental and asset retirement obligations by selecting an approved payment&#13;method. The Company has elected to meet its obligation by making an initial payment of approximately $25,300 and quarterly payments&#13;of approximately $4,700 into a trust that over the expected lease period will build liquid assets to meet the asset retirement&#13;obligation. For the fiscal years ended June 30, 2015 and 2014, the trust account balance was $67,400 and $48,700, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsAndEnvironmentalCostPolicyTextBlock>    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;A reconciliation of anticipated statutory rates is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%;    &lt;td style="width: 3%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font-weight: bold; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: center; width: 16%"&gt;2015&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 2%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 3%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font-weight: bold; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: center; width: 15%"&gt;2014&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Net operating loss and capital loss carryforwards&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;7,800,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;9,200,000&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Less: Valuation allowance&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;(7,800,000)&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;(9,200,000)&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="background-color: white"&gt;Net deferred tax&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; background-color: white"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;A valuation allowance is recognized&#13;if it is more likely than not that some or all of the deferred income tax assets will not be realized. A valuation allowance is&#13;used to offset the related income tax assets due to uncertainties of realizing the benefits of certain net operating loss and tax&#13;credits. The valuation allowance, which reflects a 100% reserve for all years reported above, decreased $1,400,000 from June 30,&#13;2014 to June 30, 2015 primarily due to the expiration of state operating loss carryforwards. At June 30, 2015, the Company had&#13;net operating loss carry-forwards for federal tax purposes of approximately $33,500,000. The loss carry-forwards, unless utilized,&#13;will expire from 2017 through 2034. With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state and local examinations&#13;by tax authorities for years before 2010.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Internal Revenue Code Section 382 limits&#13;the ability to utilize net operating losses if a 50% change in ownership occurs over a three year period. Such limitation of the&#13;net operating losses may have occurred which the Company has not fully analyzed at this time as the deferred tax asset is fully&#13;reserved, however, the Company has estimated a limitation effect on deferred tax assets of approximately $4 million at June 30,&#13;2015 and 2014.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-indent: 40pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;American Citizenship Center,&#13;LLC&amp;#160; &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;At June 30, 2015 and 2014 the Company&#13;had a note due from American Citizenship Center, LLC (&amp;#147;ACC&amp;#148;), a related party, with balances of $322,800 and $409,000,&#13;respectively. Refer to Note 3 &amp;#150; Note Receivable for further discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal years 2015 and 2014,&#13;the Company billed ACC a total of $46,300 and $73,100, respectively, which includes amounts for accounting services, legal services&#13;related to note modifications, and interest on the note. At June 30, 2015, the Company had unpaid receivables from ACC in the amount&#13;of $4,200, consisting of $2,500 representing one month of interest plus $1,700 of legal services. Subsequent to year end, ACC made&#13;payments bringing these balances current. At June 30, 2014, the Company had unpaid receivables from ACC in the amount of $9,200,&#13;consisting of $6,000 in billings for accounting services and $3,200 representing one month of interest.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Board of Directors&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company made cash payments of $7,500&#13;to each of the Company&amp;#146;s three independent members of the Board of Directors and issued each 25,000 stock grants for a total&#13;of 75,000 shares valued at $31,500. The Company recorded $16,500 of expense related to the stock grants during the current fiscal&#13;year and had accrued $15,000 at June 30, 2014. In addition, each independent director received 80,000 stock options during fiscal&#13;year 2015. Each independent director received cash payments of $2,250 during fiscal 2014. In November 2014, the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;Board of Directors approved a change to the independent director compensation. Effective January 1, 2015, the three independent&#13;directors were paid cash compensation of $1,000 each per month (included in the above totals).&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Employment agreements&lt;/b&gt; - On June&#13;30, 2014, the Company entered into employment agreements, effective July 1, 2014 with the Company&amp;#146;s newly elected Chief Executive&#13;and Chief Financial Officers. The elections resulted due to the March 2014 death of Robert Kauffman, past President and CEO of&#13;the Company. The employment agreements provide for levels of compensation and continuation of benefit under Company benefit plans.&#13;The agreements have severance provisions and are effective until 18 months after notice of termination is given by either party.&#13;Copies of the employment agreements were attached as exhibits to the Form 8-K filed on July 1, 2014.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Leases &amp;#150; &lt;/b&gt;The Company&amp;#146;s&#13;corporate office is located at 7950 E. Acoma Drive, Suite 111, Scottsdale, Arizona 85260, in an approximately 1,500 square foot&#13;facility. At June 30, 2015 the facility was occupied on a month to month basis with monthly payments of $1,700 (including rental&#13;tax). Effective August 1, 2015, the month to month payment increased to $1,800 (including rental tax).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The ten year land lease related to&#13;Deer Creek, was effective May 1, 2012 and has two additional ten year option periods that may be activated by AES. The initial&#13;terms of the lease requires minimum monthly lease payments of $100 per acre (increasing to $150 and $200 per acre for the second&#13;and third ten year option periods, respectively) plus additional royalty payments based upon quantities of produced water received&#13;(approximately $.25 per barrel) at the site. The design and construction of the Deer Creek water disposal facility required certain&#13;changes to the Goodwin Solid Waste facility resulting in extra costs to the landlord (owner of Goodwin Solid Waste). As incentive&#13;for the landlord to approve the facility design, AES agreed to limit landlord construction improvement costs related to the leased&#13;land to $200,000. Included in the $200,000 limited amount was $100,000 of landlord improvement costs to be paid by AES and reimbursed&#13;through a 50% credit against the $.25 per barrel royalty payments due to the landlord discussed above. Under certain circumstances,&#13;the acreage covered by the lease may be expanded by up to 50 acres to allow for additional expansion at the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In May 2015, AES signed a one year&#13;lease for an approximately 700 square foot office space located at 138 S. Park Square, Suite 201, Fruita, Colorado 81521 with monthly&#13;rental payments of $700 (including rental tax).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Rent expense for the fiscal years ended&#13;June 30, 2015 and 2014 were $53,300 and $50,200, respectively. Future minimum non-contingent payments as of June 30, 2015 are as&#13;follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="4" style="font-weight: bold; text-align: center"&gt;FUTURE MINIMUM PAYMENTS&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="4" style="font-weight: bold; border-bottom: Black 0.5pt solid; text-align: center"&gt;FOR THE YEAR ENDED JUNE 30,&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center; width: 25%"&gt;2016&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center; width: 25%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center; width: 8%"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; width: 32%"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;35,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;2017&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;28,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;2018&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;28,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;2019&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;28,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center; background-color: white"&gt;2020&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font-family: Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;28,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: left"&gt;Thereafter&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;52,400&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: center"&gt;TOTAL&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;202,400&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Legal Proceedings&lt;i&gt; &lt;/i&gt;&amp;#150;&#13;&lt;/b&gt;The Company is a defendant and counterclaimant in litigation involving its subsidiary, TSI Dissolution Corp. (formerly known&#13;as Alanco/TSI Prism, Inc.) (&amp;#147;TSI&amp;#148;) and the purchaser of TSI&amp;#146;s assets, Black Creek Integrated Systems Corp. Black&#13;Creek filed a complaint in the Maricopa County Superior Court against TSI and the Company, being Civil Case NO. CV2011-014175,&#13;claiming various offsets from the purchase price, primarily concerning inventory adjustments, and TSI counterclaimed for monies&#13;due from Black Creek under the purchase agreement. Following a trial during fiscal 2014, the court awarded a net judgment in favor&#13;of Black Creek in the amount of $16,800, plus attorney&amp;#146;s fees and accrued interest, resulting in a total judgment in the&#13;amount of $128,300. At June 30, 2014, the Company recorded an accrued liability of $128,300 for the judgment and had posted a bond&#13;with the court in conjunction with the Company&amp;#146;s appeal of the judgment. In May 2015, the State of Arizona Division One Court&#13;of Appeals vacated the trial court&amp;#146;s damages award and remanded to the trial court to direct the parties to follow dispute&#13;guidelines defined in the asset purchase agreement. In addition, the appellate court&amp;#146;s decision vacated the trial court&amp;#146;s&#13;attorney&amp;#146;s fee award and stated that TSI is entitled to an award of fees on appeal. At June 30, 2015, the Company reversed&#13;the accrual of $128,300 for the prior judgment. The Company is currently following the court&amp;#146;s direction and working under&#13;the dispute guidelines defined in the asset purchase agreement. The Company believes that the lower court&amp;#146;s judgment failed&#13;to address, among other matters, inventory reserves established for the specific items of inventory which were the subject of Black&#13;Creek&amp;#146;s concerns, which if properly addressed would result in a net judgment in favor of the Company, with an attendant award&#13;of attorney&amp;#146;s fees in favor of the Company. Therefore, no accrual for the loss contingency was deemed necessary at June 30,&#13;2015.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company may from time to time be&#13;involved in litigation arising from the normal course of business.&amp;#160; As of June 30, 2015, other than the litigation discussed&#13;above, there was no such litigation pending deemed material by the Company.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:StockholdersEquityNoteDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Preferred Shares &lt;/b&gt;&amp;#150; the&#13;Company has 25,000,000 authorized no par shares of Preferred Stock of which 5,000,000 have been allocated to Series A, 500,000&#13;have been allocated to Series B, 400,000 have been allocated to Series C Junior Participating, 500,000 have been allocated to Series&#13;D, and 750,000 have been allocated to Series E. As of June 30, 2015 and 2014, no Preferred Stock of any series is issued or outstanding.&#13;The Board of Directors is authorized to issue preferred stock in one or more series and denominations and to fix the rights, preferences,&#13;privileges, and restrictions, including dividend, conversion, voting, redemption, liquidation rights or preferences, and the number&#13;of shares constituting any series and the designation of such series, without any further vote or action by our shareholders.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Common Shares&lt;/b&gt; - The authorized&#13;capital stock of the Company consists of 75,000,000 shares of no par Class A Common Stock, each entitled to one vote per share,&#13;and 25,000,000 shares of no par Class B Common Stock, each entitled to one-one hundredth (1/100th) of one vote per share. No Class&#13;B Common Stock has been issued and none was outstanding at June 30, 2015 and 2014.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During fiscal year ended June 30, 2015,&#13;the Company issued 75,000 shares of Class A Common Stock for services valued at $31,500. During the same period, the Company repurchased&#13;and retired 55,100 shares for $20,800 resulting in a 55,100 reduction in outstanding shares of Common Stock. The value of stock-based&#13;compensation recognized during fiscal year ended June 30, 2015 was $41,800.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During fiscal year ended June 30, 2014,&#13;the Company issued 30,000 shares of Class A Common Stock for services valued at $11,700. During the same period, the Company repurchased&#13;and retired 56,800 shares for $26,100 resulting in a 56,800 reduction in outstanding shares of Common Stock. There was no stock-based&#13;compensation recognized during the fiscal year ended June 30, 2014.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During the year ended June 30, 2015,&#13;the Company recognized a comprehensive income adjustment in the amount of ($121,200), reported in the Consolidated Statement of&#13;Changes in Shareholders&amp;#146; Equity. During the year ended June 30, 2014, the Company recognized a comprehensive income adjustment&#13;in the amount of ($428,700), reported in the Consolidated Statement of Changes in Shareholders&amp;#146; Equity. See Note 4 &amp;#150;&#13;Marketable Securities, for additional discussion of fair value of financial instruments and marketable securities.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;On December 12, 2011 the Company announced&#13;that its board of directors had authorized a stock repurchase program whereby the Company could repurchase up to 2 million shares&#13;of its outstanding common stock over the next 12 months. The stock repurchase program was extended, under the same limitation,&#13;through December 31, 2013. During the quarter ended March 31, 2014, the board of directors renewed the stock repurchase program,&#13;extending it through December 31, 2014 and establishing an aggregate future amount of shares that may be purchased under the program&#13;to 2 million shares. During the quarter ended December 31, 2014, the board of directors again renewed the stock purchase program,&#13;extending it through December 31, 2015. For the year ended June 30, 2015, the Company had repurchases under the program for a total&#13;of 55,100 shares at a cost of approximately $20,800, or $0.38 per share.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:StockholdersEquityNoteDisclosureTextBlock>    <us-gaap:CompensationAndEmployeeBenefitPlansTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company provides a 401(k) retirement&#13;plan for its employees. Employees are eligible to participate in the plan on the first of the month following 90 days of continuous&#13;employment. Employee salary deferral rates are not restricted by the Company, however, IRS limits and limitations imposed by discrimination&#13;tests may affect the allowed salary deferral rate. Through the quarter ended December 31, 2013, the Company had a matching program&#13;equivalent to 25% of the amount deferred by employees, matching up to 4% of an employee&amp;#146;s annual compensation. Effective&#13;January 1, 2014 and due to regulations for top heavy compliance, the Company adopted Safe Harbor provision in the 401(k) retirement&#13;plan which requires all employees receive a 3% match based on gross wages. The Company&amp;#146;s matching contributions totaled $12,000&#13;and $7,900 for the years ended June 30, 2015 and 2014, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CompensationAndEmployeeBenefitPlansTextBlock>    <us-gaap:SubstantialDoubtAboutGoingConcernTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal years ended June&#13;30, 2015 and 2014, the Company reported a net loss of ($900,600) and ($106,200), respectively and operating loss of ($1,173,800)&#13;and ($1,077,200), respectively. Historically, the Company had relied on the liquidation of its investment in Marketable Securities&#13;to fund working capital needs. The Company sold all remaining marketable securities during fiscal 2015. These factors raise doubt&#13;about the Company&amp;#146;s ability to continue as a going concern for the next year. The Company&amp;#146;s fiscal 2016 operating plan&#13;contemplates development of the AES Indian Mesa site. In order to develop the Indian Mesa site, the Company will need additional&#13;financing which may be in the form of public or private debt or equity financing, or both. Management cannot assure that it will&#13;secure additional financing in order to achieve projections. If adequate funds are not available or are not available on acceptable&#13;terms, the Company&amp;#146;s business, operating results, financial condition and ability to continue operations may be materially&#13;adversely affected. Management has historically been successful in obtaining financing and has demonstrated the ability to implement&#13;a number of cost-cutting initiatives to reduce working capital needs or the Company may seek to sell assets. Accordingly, the accompanying&#13;consolidated financial statements have been prepared assuming the Company will continue to operate and do not include any adjustment&#13;that might be necessary if the Company is unable to continue as a going concern. As a result, the Company&amp;#146;s independent registered&#13;public accounting firm has included an explanatory paragraph in their audit opinion on the consolidated financial statements of&#13;the Company for the fiscal year ended June 30, 2015 discussing the substantial doubt of the Company&amp;#146;s ability to continue&#13;as a going concern.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:SubstantialDoubtAboutGoingConcernTextBlock>    <us-gaap:SubsequentEventsTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Subsequent to June 30, 2015 ACC paid&#13;$17,200 in principal payments and brought all amounts due current. In August 2015, ACC and the Company amended the loan agreement&#13;by extending the maturity date to August 31, 2017. All other terms of the note, including the interest rate of 9.5% and the minimum&#13;monthly required payments of the greater of $5,000 or 10% of ACC&amp;#146;s gross monthly revenues remained the same. Based on the&#13;minimum required payments, the Company has classified $60,000 of the note as current, and $262,800 of the note as long-term as&#13;of June 30, 2015.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:SubsequentEventsTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:NatureOfOperations contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Nature of Operations&lt;/b&gt; - Alanco&#13;Technologies, Inc. (Stock Symbol: ALAN) was incorporated in 1969 under the laws of the State of Arizona. Unless otherwise noted,&#13;the &amp;#34;Company&amp;#34; or &amp;#147;Alanco&amp;#148; refers to Alanco Technologies, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries. During the&#13;fiscal year ended June 30, 2012, the Company formed Alanco Energy Services, Inc. (&amp;#147;AES&amp;#148;), for the purpose of obtaining&#13;property to establish a water disposal facility near Grand Junction, CO to receive produced water generated as a byproduct from&#13;oil and natural gas production in Western Colorado. The new facility started to receive produced water in August 2012. See Note&#13;5 - Alanco Energy Services for discussion of AES transactions.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:NatureOfOperations>
    <us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Principles of Consolidation&lt;/b&gt;&#13;&amp;#150; These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted&#13;in the United States (GAAP). The consolidated financial statements for the years ended June 30, 2015 and 2014 include, where appropriate,&#13;the accounts of Alanco Technologies, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, Alanco Energy Services, Inc. and StarTrak Systems,&#13;LLC (&amp;#147;StarTrak&amp;#148;) (collectively, the &amp;#147;Company&amp;#148;). Alanco is an Arizona corporation, Alanco Energy Services,&#13;Inc. is a Colorado corporation and StarTrak is a Delaware LLC. All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been&#13;eliminated in consolidation.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:Reclassifications contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Reclassifications&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; Certain&#13;prior year numbers have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation. Sales tax on certain revenues for the fiscal&#13;year 2014 that were classified as cost of revenues has been reclassified in the Consolidated Statement of Operations to offset&#13;revenues to conform to the current year&amp;#146;s presentation. This reclassification had no effect on net loss or net loss per share.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:Reclassifications>
    <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Cash and Cash Equivalents&lt;/b&gt; -&#13;The Company considers all highly liquid instruments with maturities of three months or less at the time of purchase to be cash&#13;equivalents.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Revenue Recognition&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150;&#13;The Company operates the Deer Creek water disposal facility near Grand Junction, CO and bills customers (primarily in the oil and&#13;gas industry) for produced water received. The Company generally recognizes revenue at the time the produced water is received&#13;at the Deer Creek facility, filtered and billed. In addition, the Company has revenue from oil reclamation and generally recognizes&#13;oil revenue when the oil is picked up by the customer. Water and related oil revenues can be impacted by weather conditions and&#13;the prices of oil and gas which may impact drilling activities. Revenue is generally recognized when all the following have been&#13;met:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 45pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 45pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;The service has been performed or product&#13;delivered;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 45pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;The customer&amp;#146;s fee is deemed to be&#13;determinable and free of contingencies or significant uncertainties; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 45pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 18pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;Collectability is probable.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27pt"&gt;Any sales tax for which the&#13;Company is responsible is recorded as a reduction of the associated revenue.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock>    <us-gaap:ReceivablesPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Accounts Receivable - Trade and&#13;Other&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; The Company provides for potentially uncollectible trade accounts receivable and other receivables by use of&#13;the allowance method. An allowance for doubtful accounts is provided based upon a review of the individual accounts outstanding,&#13;the Company&amp;#146;s prior history of collections and the customer&amp;#146;s credit worthiness. The Company charges off uncollectible&#13;receivables when all reasonable collection efforts have been exhausted. The Company does not typically accrue interest or fees&#13;on past due amounts and the receivables are generally unsecured. The Company&amp;#146;s allowance for doubtful accounts receivable&#13;was approximately $0 and $1,000 at June 30, 2015 and 2014, respectively. No allowance was established as of June 30, 2015 as all&#13;receivables were deemed fully collectible.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ReceivablesPolicyTextBlock>    <us-gaap:FinanceLoansAndLeasesReceivablePolicy contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Notes Receivable&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; The&#13;Company provides for potentially uncollectible notes receivable by use of the allowance method. An allowance for uncollectible&#13;notes receivable is provided based upon a review of the individual notes outstanding and the note holder&amp;#146;s credit worthiness.&#13;The Company charges off uncollectible notes receivable when all reasonable collection efforts have been exhausted. Interest income&#13;from notes receivable is recognized when earned. There was no allowance for doubtful notes receivable at June 30, 2015 and 2014.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:FinanceLoansAndLeasesReceivablePolicy>
    <us-gaap:MarketableSecuritiesPolicy contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Marketable Securities &amp;#150; &lt;/b&gt;The&#13;Company determines the appropriate classification of its investments in marketable equity securities at the time of acquisition&#13;and re-evaluates such determinations at each balance sheet date. Marketable securities are classified as held to maturity when&#13;the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold securities to maturity. Marketable securities that are bought and held&#13;principally for the purpose of selling them in the near term are classified as trading securities and are reported at fair value,&#13;with the unrealized gains and losses recognized in earnings. Marketable securities not classified as held to maturity or as trading,&#13;are classified as available for sale, and are carried at fair value, with the unrecognized gains and losses, net of tax, included&#13;in the determination of comprehensive income (loss) and reported in shareholders&amp;#146; equity. The Company measures and discloses&#13;its investments in marketable securities, which are classified as available for sale, at fair value on a recurring basis, in accordance&#13;with the Accounting Standards Codification (&amp;#147;ASC&amp;#148;). The cost of the securities sold is based on average cost of the&#13;security.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The fair value of substantially all&#13;securities is determined by quoted market prices. The estimated fair value of securities for which there are no quoted market prices&#13;is based on similar types of securities that are traded in the market.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:MarketableSecuritiesPolicy>    <us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2014-07-01to2015-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Fair Value of Assets and Liabilities&lt;/b&gt;&#13;&amp;#150; The estimated fair values for assets and liabilities are determined at discrete points in time based on relevant information.&#13;The ASC prioritizes inputs used in measuring fair value into a hierarchy of three levels: Level 1 &amp;#150; unadjusted quoted prices&#13;for identical assets or liabilities traded in active markets, Level 2 &amp;#150; observable inputs, other than quoted prices included&#13;within Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities, quoted prices in markets that are not active or other&#13;inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the asset or liability;&#13;and Level 3 &amp;#150; unobservable inputs in which little or no market activity exists that are significant to the fair value of&#13;the assets or liabilities, therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions that market participants would use in pricing.&#13;These estimates involve uncertainties and cannot be determined with precision. The Company&amp;#146;s policy is to recognize transfers&#13;into and out of Level 1, 2 and 3 categories as of the date of the event or change in circumstances occurs.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The following are the classes of assets&#13;and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis at June 30, 2015 and 2014, using quoted prices in active markets for&#13;identical assets (Level 1); significant other observable inputs (Level 2); and significant unobservable inputs (Level 3):&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="9" style="font-weight: bold; text-align: center"&gt;Fair Value at June 30, 2015&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font-family: Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif;
